entry.et: Spanish tabaco, probably from Taino, roll of tobacco leaves

def.dt: :any of a genus (Nicotiana) of chiefly American plants of the nightshade family with viscid foliage and tubular flowers
:a tall erect annual tropical American herb (North tabacum) cultivated for its leaves
:the leaves of cultivated tobacco prepared for use in smoking or chewing or as snuff
:manufactured products of tobacco (as cigars or cigarettes)
:smoking as a practice has sworn off tobacco
:an American noctuid moth (Heliothis virescens syn. Helicoverpa virescens) whose striped and variably colored larva feeds on buds and young leaves especially of tobacco and cotton
:an American hawk moth (Manduca sexta) whose large usually green larva is a hornworm that feeds on the leaves of plants of the nightshade family and especially tobacco and tomato
:saliva colored brown by tobacco or snuff

:a single-stranded RNA virus (species Tobacco mosaic virus of the genus Tobamovirus) that occurs worldwide and causes mosaic disease in plants (as tobacco and tomato) especially of the nightshade family

entry.et: from Tobacco Road, novel (1932) by Erskine Caldwell and play (1933) by Jack Kirkland †1969 American playwright

def.dt: :a squalid poverty-stricken rural area or community
:a poisonous North American annual lobelia (Lobelia inflata) with small blue or white flowers
:a wild tobacco (Nicotiana bigelovii syn. North quadrivalvis) found in dry valleys from southern California to southern Oregon
:pulverized or shredded tobacco chewed or placed between cheek and gum :snuff
